questions.question: 2. In the neuromuscular junction, what happens after Na+ ions get into the synaptic gutter?
options: Ca+2 ions get into the synaptic knob

questions.question: 4. Neuromuscular transmission:
options: Is caused by release of acetylcholine from the muscle side of the M.E.P.
Is blocked by curare because it competes with Na+ influx at the M.E.P.
Is accelerated by hexamethonium and botulinum toxin.
Shows a permeability change to Na+ and K+ at the receptor side of the neuromuscular transmission

questions.question: 8. At the NMJ:
options: The muscle membrane possesses muscarinic receptors.
There's a one-to-one transmission of excitatory impulses from the motor neuron to the muscle fibres it innervates
The motor nerve endings secret noradrenaline
The typical summed end plate potential is usually 10 times the potential necessary to trigger an action potential

questions.question: 9. During neuromuscular transmission, the arrival of nerve action potential at the synaptic knob leads to which of the following:
10. The correct temporal sequence for events at the NMJ:
options: AP in the motor nerve, depolarization of muscle end plate, uptake of Ca+2 into the presynaptic nerve terminal
Uptake of Ca+2 into the presynaptic nerve terminal, release of ACh, depolarization of muscle end plate
Release of ACh, AP in motor nerve, AP in the muscle
Uptake of Ca+2 into the presynaptic nerve terminal, AP in motor end plate, AP in the muscle
